thread.title: Editorial: Police victims of city, county games

author: DispatchDaemon
title: Editorial: Police victims of city, county games
text:
Chatham County commissioners are scheduled to vote today on a unanimous recommendation from the Savannah-Chatham police policy committee to contribute more than $279,000 to salary increases for police.
It should be a slam-dunk, 9-0 vote. But given the sorry state of local politics and the poor history of city-county cooperation, nothing is a guarantee these days.
While money will be an issue on the minds of some of the commissioners, the county vote is more about the political football the city and county have been playing with police officers for too long.
Local politicians in both the county and the city have rightly cited the importance of public safety and recruiting more police officers during a year when violent crime is skyrocketing in the city and unincorporated areas of the county. Yet, like two teams trying to make sure they don’t get hoodwinked by their opponents, the city and county keep kicking the ball back and forth.
The trouble is that police officers are not footballs. They are the front line battling the violent crime that is taking a serious toll on citizens and hurting Savannah’s image as the “Hostess City of the South.” Instead of supporting them, too many elected officials have given them the backs of their hands.
It wasn’t police officers who appointed a corrupt police chief — Willie Lovett — who is now sitting in a federal penitentiary after his conviction on racketeering. The city and county managers put him in charge, with the blessings of the politicians who were running the show.
It wasn’t police officers who allowed the police force to evaporate by 100 officers. That came from the high-ups, too.
It wasn’t police officers who allowed police salaries to fall well below the average of cities and counties around the Southeast, giving badly needed, experienced officers all the more reason to look for jobs elsewhere.
And it’s not police officers who have been used as the subject of finger-pointing by our City Council and county commissioners who blame each other for the failure of the raises to go through.
The incredible mess that the public and police have been exposed to during the past five months shows that while politicians talk the talk, they don’t walk the walk. They certainly don’t walk, or patrol, the beat in some pretty dangerous neighborhoods, putting their lives on the line, for the pittance they formerly were paid. The raises were designed to help police recruit more applicants and provide current officers with a much-needed living wage.
Instead, the public spectacle waged by council members and commissioners demonstrates less concern for police officers and more concern with their own political agendas and tender egos, selfishly choosing who can make the other side blink first. We urge the county commission to approve the police policy committee’s recommendation during today’s meeting.
Next up is the City Council, which had the opportunity to pass the police merger agreement Oct. 15, but chose instead to wait until their next meeting, Friday, Oct. 29. They need to adopt the extension of the current police merger and show they really care about public safety. Neither political group is a winner. But don’t make our police the losers. They’re the MVPs who need everyone’s support at this time in our community’s history.
